Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: All questions

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The overall standard of student responses in the 2024 examination was very high. It is clear that students are preparing across the whole study design: the set text, relevant themes, and in particular the passages for special study. Most students can, at the least, provide relevant responses to questions.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Higher-scoring responses answered in line with the VCAA published command terms, which in the 2024 examination were almost identical to previous years. The command terms are typical of scriptural scholarship, and are therefore typical of most VCE Texts and Traditions exams. The command terms were:

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Analyse

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Compare

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Define

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Describe

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Discuss

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Explain

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Explain with the use of two examples

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Identify

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Illustrate your response

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Name

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Outline

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Select and discuss

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Use examples to support your response

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: What is ...?

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Who was ...?

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The short-answer questions in Part 1 and most of the essay questions have multiple parts; this provides a guide for students to structure their responses.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: It is safe to assume that questions will be different from previous years, especially the parts of compulsory Question 4, so it is advised that students read all parts of the chosen question. High-scoring responses answered the actual question that was asked.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Most students paid attention to the multiple parts of the questions, and used these parts to help structure their responses.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Students are reminded to write their answers in English. There are no extra marks for words or phrases written in Hebrew, Greek or Arabic.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Higher-scoring responses incorporated quotations. However, if students are unsure whether the quotation is accurate, it is preferable to paraphrase a scholar - that is, not to use quotation marks but rather to write, for example, 'Scholar A says that ...'

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Students are to be commended on following instructions in the Answer Book. This enabled students to answer questions more fully, especially Question 4.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: It is important for students to indicate the correct answer at the top of the appropriate page in the Answer Book, and to ensure that only one question is answered per page. It is not necessary to write out the question. Responses that are continued in the extra space provided must be labelled to indicate they are 'continued', so that the examiner knows to continue reading and awarding marks.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Note: Student responses reproduced in this report have not been corrected for grammar, spelling or factual information.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: This report provides sample answers or an indication of what answers may have included. Unless otherwise stated, these are not intended to be exemplary or complete responses.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The statistics in this report may be subject to rounding resulting in a total more or less than 100 per cent.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: This part of the examination is almost always from Unit 3 Outcomes 1 and 2. Questions 1-3 are worth 10 marks each. Each question has two to three parts, and each part has marks awarded to it.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: High-scoring responses answered each part of the chosen questions, and demonstrated familiarity with the command terms in addressing the questions.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Lower-scoring responses tended to not answer all parts of the question, not follow the command terms, include material that was not directly relevant to the question, or were too brief to fully answer the question.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Some students wrote very long responses, almost to the length of an essay, going into more detail than was required to answer the question.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Statistics for this examination cover all four tradition strand questions; it is not possible to provide statistics on individual questions. The average mark for Questions 1-3 across the four tradition strands ranged between 5.6 and 6.1. Five to 10 per cent of attempted responses did not address the question.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: It is important that students show an understanding of specialist terms by providing a clear definition or by demonstrating understanding through their discussion. Responses can then be marked within that understanding of the term.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The spread of marks over the four strands of the study were as follows.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: 2024 VCE Texts and Traditions external assessment report

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Each part of Question 4 is dependent on Unit 4 Outcome 3 of the study design. For this compulsory question, many students may benefit from knowing how a theme in the set text has been reapplied, reinterpreted, re-contextualised, referred to, or used by the tradition over a period of time discernibly later than the original set text. High-scoring responses answered all parts of the question. Familiarity with the study design may assist students to prepare for this question.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Question 4 is the same question across the four tradition strands. Students should note, however, that the question is not repeated from year to year. Many students in the 2024 examination provided responses to Question 4 from the 2023 examination.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Eight per cent of responses did not name a textual theme studied in Unit 4 Outcome 3. These responses therefore were also not successful in outlining a theme. Some responses discussed more than one textual theme; however the question, and the study design, asks for only one textual theme from the set text.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Students should only refer to textual themes that come directly from the set text. Students should not need to refer to sacred texts outside the set text in order to explain the textual theme.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Nearly 15 per cent of responses were not able to discuss how the later tradition explained its interpretation of the theme or changes that may have occurred over time, and nearly 25 per cent of responses did not successfully explain the relevance of the original text to the later tradition's understanding of the textual theme.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Most students correctly used the Answer Book to structure their responses into the three separate parts of the question.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The brief excerpts from student responses that follow are not intended to be used as a template, but to demonstrate how some students successfully responded to Question 4 on the 2024 examination.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The following is an example of a high-scoring response:
Example: 'Messianism was considered used as a tool of hope for the prophets Jeremiah and Ezekiel, as their prophetic ministries were amidst a period ... when the destruction of Judah was looming ...'

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The following is an example of a high-scoring response:
Example: 'Through the characters of Mary, Elizabeth ... Luke portrayed not only their complete faith in God but the potential for women ... to access the Kingdom of God. The development of the idea of women had been slowly infiltrating religious institution such as ...'

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The following is an example of a high-scoring response:
Example: 'The theme of Jesus being the "Word" from "the beginning" was a pivotal concept ... highlighting the divine ... identity of Jesus. This theme [was] developed and ... interpreted by ... Arius who ... opposed the concept of Jesus being a divine being.'

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The following is an example of a high-scoring response:
Example: 'The textual theme Shirk (polytheism) [is] prevalent in Surah Baqarah through the damnation of idol-worship and emphasis on Allah's attributes ... In parallel, Ibn Taymmiyah's simplification of the textual themes served to [...] through simplification for easier comprehension of the theme.'

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The following is an example of a high-scoring response:
Example: 'The later tradition, particularly the reform sect of Judaism explained their interpretation by affirming that [Jewish Law] "is our guidance, not our governance (Rabbi Solomon Freehoff), and thus they were not required to take the descriptions ... [literally].'

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The following is an example of a high-scoring response:
Example: 'William and Catherine Booth, the founders of the Salvation Army explained their interpretation of the Kingdom of God by re-asserting that all people require a Saviour and that the marginalized are not to be excluded ... demonstrating an evolution in how the kingdom of God is preserved and shared.'

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The following is an example of a high-scoring response:
Example: '... This sparked controversy in the Church at the time and the first Council of Nicea was call to define the nature of [Jesus].'

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The following is an example of a high-scoring response:
Example: 'Through Ijma (Islamic law) and Qiyas, modern scholars have been able to interpret Shirk to beyond physical idol worshipping ...'

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The following is an example of a high-scoring response:
Example: 'Reform radically shifted the belief, holding it as partially relevant to the way the prophets taught Messianism ... they hoped for Messianism to be a "kingdom of truth, peace and justice" (Pittsburgh Platform).'

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The following is an example of a high-scoring response:
Example: 'In the "Manchester Statement", they referenced Luke 8:1-3 as an example of women providing support for Jesus' ministry by their "own resources." The Anglican Church claimed that this was exemplary of women's importance in the kingdom of God ...'

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The following is an example of a high-scoring response:
Example: 'John's Gospel ... is relevant to the notion of Jesus' identity... through his representation of the Father and Son relationship ... The later tradition provided a similar idea ... which ultimately supports the belief ... that he was a human in his nature as well as ... divine'

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The following is an example of a high-scoring response:
Example: 'The Qur'an ... continually condemns the act of shirk which remains relevant to Islam ... "Do not commit shirk". This serves as the framework [for] Islam.'

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The average mark for the exegesis questions was 18 out of a possible 30 marks. Approximately 40 per cent of responses achieved more than 20 marks; 45 per cent achieved between 10 and 20 marks.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: High-scoring responses:

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Included good exegetical method

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Included analysis, not just a summary of the passage

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Commented on the sociocultural or historical (if appropriate) and literary context of the passage

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Used signposting, such as 'A literary form found in this passage ...'

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Explored the use of literary forms and techniques, such as metaphors; rhetorical questions; end stress; and grouping of passages or ayahs or verses and their effect within the passage, section, or whole set text

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Provided informed discussion on themes found within the text

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Provided explicit reference to the meaning for the original audience or receivers of the text; for example, 'From this passage, the original audience would have learnt that ...'

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Analysed the passage as a connected whole, rather than ayah by ayah, or verse by verse

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Discussed whole bolded phrases, rather than discussing separate, individual words within the phrase

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Were able to demonstrate scholarly opinion; some students were able to name scholars.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The average mark for the essay questions was 16 out of a possible 30 marks. Approximately 33 per cent of responses achieved more than 20 marks; 47 per cent achieved between 10 and 20 marks.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: High-scoring responses usually:

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Answered all parts of the question

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Clearly indicated an understanding of the key terms of the question. Note that students should not take for granted a common understanding of terminology, and should express their understanding of key terms in their introduction

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Included references to passages and an explanation as to how various passages showed the theme or idea

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Used an essay structure similar to that used in VCE English, which tended to lead to the development of a strong argument

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Discussed a passage's implications rather than retelling the content of a passage

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Moved beyond summary.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Essays that were not well developed or were poorly structured were not able to achieve high grades.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Students are reminded to follow the directions within the question when crafting their response. For instance if three examples are specified in the question, it is not useful to include more than three examples in the response.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: All questions

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: 2025 VCE Texts and Traditions external assessment report

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: This report provides sample answers or an indication of what answers may have included. These are not intended to be exemplary or complete responses.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The statistics in this report may be subject to rounding, resulting in a total of more or less than 100 per cent.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Note: Student responses reproduced in this report have not been corrected for grammar, spelling or factual information. Student responses have been redacted to illustrate the relevant assessed aspects of the response.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The extended responses are directly related to the passages, themes and ideas from the 2025 passages for special study. This part of the examination is almost always from Unit 3 outcomes 1 and 2. Questions 1-3 were worth 10 marks each. All the questions consisted of two or three parts, and each part had marks awarded to it. High-scoring answers addressed each part of the question, clearly signposting the individual parts of the question, and often in separate paragraphs.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Low-scoring responses did not answer all parts of the question or included non-relevant information or discussion. Setting a time allocation may assist.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Students must show care to respond to the set text they have studied.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: In Question 1 from the Qur'an section, students were required to use two examples from Surah 19 to outline the concern of Maryam, explain Maryam's predicament and discuss how her people reacted to her miraculous conception.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The following is from a high-scoring response:

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Example: After angel Jibraeel descended by the command of Allah and announced that Maryam would give birth to a child she was concerned of how she could possibly give birth when... After she had given birth her concern changed into how she would return to her village ...  Just as Maryam worried, the people of her village upon seeing a baby ... began to question how she could possibly have given birth when... However, after Isa spoke on behalf of his mother the people ceased their queries understanding that her son was ...

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Students were required to explain why examples of fulfilment of messianic prophecy included in the Passion narrative are used for John's audience, using two examples and explaining the significance of each example.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The following is an example from a high-scoring response:
Example: There are numerous examples of fulfillment of messianic prophecies in the Passion narrative. Such fulfillments of prophecy were of profound significance ... as it communicated to them that their faith ... One such prophecy that is fulfilled ... is that of the suffering servant (Isaiah 52 and 53) [which] speaks of ... Another messianic prophecy that is fulfilled in the passion narrative is that of Zechariah ...

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Students were required to explain the significance of Chapter 2 and discuss what the chapter tells us about the Kingdom of God, using two examples to support their response.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The following is an example from a high-scoring response:
Example: Chapter 2, which outlines the birth and childhood of Jesus, significantly underscores the beginning of Jesus' life, death and resurrection, and frames the understanding of his identity ... The chapter further emphasises the proclamation of the kingdom of God ... The boy Jesus in the temple indicates this understanding ... in the role that Jesus plays in promoting the kingdom. The chapter confirms their place within the kingdom ...

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: High-scoring responses addressed all three parts of the question.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Many lower-scoring responses provided content and discussion more appropriate to past examination questions.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Some low-scoring responses did not name a theme from the set text, did not name a particular period of history later than the formation of the set text or did not discuss how the later interpretations affected the religious tradition. Some lower-scoring responses provided historical summaries but did not link them to the questions.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The following are examples from high-scoring responses.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Example: In the early 1900s, the viewpoint of women in society began to shift with the suffrage movement ... thus inciting questions within the church about the ability of women ... Particularly, in a speech ... in 1987 [which stated] ...

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Example: Over time ... ideas about Jesus were greatly divided ... One proponent of these ideas was Arius, who lived ... Arianism was refuted by the Council of Nicaea in 325 CE, in favour of consubstantiality ...

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Example: During the period of revelation, shirk consisted of idol worship... [but] during the ... (8th-13th century), shirk shifted more to grave worship ...

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Example: Dhabiha was always traditionally done by hand ... However, during the late 1700s, the occurrence of the industrial revolution and mass production, automated slaughtering machines were created ... Soon many Muslim countries ... adopted this ... which required further analysis [for] alignment with Islamic beliefs.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The following are examples from high-scoring responses.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Example: The parable of the good Samaritan forms the foundation of social justice ... a model of faith ... a modern [interpretation] to promote the ideal of human dignity.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Example: [Based on John's Prologue] Arius justified his idea by saying that ... The Council of Nicaea disagreed, and emphasised consubstantiality in the Nicene Creed, as Jesus said he was one with the Father (10:30).

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Example: The Qur'an details the theme of shirk, by stating that Allah is One (2:163), and not to commit shirk ... Abdul Wahhab from the 17th Century used qiyas to interpret grave worship as shirk ...

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The following are examples from high-scoring responses.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Example: Various changes within the Catholic Church resulted from the reinterpretation of social justice ... sought to work with economic systems ... the reinterpretation of social justice has led to continued efforts for political [and economic] justice.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Example: This teaching significantly affected the religious tradition as it moved the church to clarify its teaching ... adoptionism was denounced as heretical ... reaffirming that Jesus is fully God and fully man.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Example: Due to scholars' interpretation of shirk and providing [new] understanding for Muslims ... believers are thus able to reflect on the various forms of shirk that emerge and understand the various ways they may fall into such acts of ... shirk.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The mean mark for the exegetical response was 18 out of a possible 30 marks. Approximately 45 per cent achieved 20 or more marks, and 46 per cent achieved 10 to 19 marks.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: High-scoring responses demonstrated:

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: A confident grasp of the required exegetical elements - context, literary analysis, themes, significance for original receivers or audience of the selected excerpts

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Solid knowledge of a range of scholars, and an ability to integrate commentary meaningfully, rather than simply quoting or listing

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: An exploration of textual layers with nuance, demonstrating understanding not only of the surface meaning but also of broader thematic, structural and theological implications.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Lower-scoring responses included:

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Sections of the exegetical exercise that were not completed

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: References or comparisons to other writings or scholarly opinion not relevant to the passage being analysed

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: References to other passages from the set text, which did not add to understanding of the context nor the analysis of the passage

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Sections from the passage that were misquoted, or analysis of ideas not found in the passage.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: The marks allocated for the essay component of the examination remains stable from year to year, with the average mark for the essay questions this year 16 out of a possible 30 marks. Approximately 37 per cent achieved 20 marks or more; 44 per cent achieved between 10 and 19 marks.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: High-scoring responses usually included:

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Discussion directly relevant to the question, including addressing key terms and theological concepts in the question

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Discussion of all parts of the question, including whether the examples or evidence were from the set text or excerpts, and the correct number of examples as nominated by the question

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Skilful scholarly opinion, including direct quotes from scholars

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Clear signposting or 'topic sentences' in the style used in English essays, used to structure the discussion of the question.

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Lower-scoring responses included:

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Discussion that did not answer all sections of the question

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Apparent misinterpretation of key terms, which led to inaccurate responses

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: References to other writings and scholars that were not directly relevant to the question

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Apparent use of prepared answers, without reference to the actual question

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Brief, or repetitive and sometimes lengthy, responses without addressing the question

Subject: Texts and Traditions
Content: Responses answering sections of the examination paper that did not apply to the relevant tradition.
